unit: Unit 9 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Slopes
title: Starting Salary vs College GPA
question_text:
Sixty-five random recent college graduates were selected and asked their college grade point average (GPA) as well as their starting salary on their first job. This resulted in a a regression equation of $\hat{y}=9.7x + 23.6$ where $x$ is GPA and $\hat{y}$ is the predicted salary (in thousands of dollars). The standard error was $0.25$.
Find a $99\%$ confidence interval for the slope and interpret it.

choices.text:
$(9.035, 10.365)$
We are $99\%$ confident that the interval from $9.035$ to $10.365$ contains the slope of the true regression line relating grade point average and starting salary. We have convincing evidence that there is an association between theses two variables.

$(9.035, 10.365)$
We are $99\%$ confident that the interval from $9.035$ to $10.365$ contains the slope of the true regression line relating grade point average and starting salary. We have convincing evidence that there is no association between theses two variables

$(9.2, 10.2)$
We are $99\%$ confident that the interval from $9.2$ to $10.2$ contains the slope of the true regression line relating grade point average and starting salary. We have convincing evidence that there is an association between theses two variables.

$(9.2, 10.2)$
We are $99\%$ confident that the interval from $9.2$ to $10.2$ contains the slope of the true regression line relating grade point average and starting salary. We have convincing evidence that there is no association between theses two variables.

(9.465,9.935)
We are 99% confident that the interval from 9.465 to 9.935 contains the slope of the true regression line relating grade point average and starting salary. We have convincing evidence that there is an association between theses two variables.

solution:
Solution

When finding a confidence interval for the slope of a regression line, the following formula should be used:

b±t∗(SEb)

...where b
is the slope of the line of best fit, t∗
is the critical value, and SEb
is the standard error of the slope.

While we are given the values for b
(9.7
, the slope from the equation) and SEb
(0.25
, the standard error), we need to use Table B
to find the value of the critical value or t∗
. Since our sample size is 65
, and we know that the degrees of freedom for this type of interval is n−2
, then we use a d.f. of 65−2=63
then dropping down to 60
to conservatively use the table. Using the 99%
confidence level column, we find a t∗
value of 2.660
.

Substituting the above values into our formula for a confidence interval we get: 9.7±(2.660)(0.25)
which simplifies to 9.7±0.665
or (9.035,10.365)
.

Now we need to interpret the interval. A standard way of describing the interval would be to say we are 99%
confident that our interval contains the true slope of our regression model. We would also include the context of the problem. In addition, we would note that, since our interval does not contain zero, we have evidence that there is an association between grade point average and starting salary.

So, Choice 'A' is correct.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'B' is incorrect because there is an association between the variables.

Choice 'C' is incorrect because the interval is mistakenly based on the critical value for a
95
%
confidence level.

Choice 'D' is incorrect because the interval is mistakenly based on the critical value for a
95
%
confidence level and because there is an association between the variables.

Choice 'E' is incorrect because a numerical mistake was made and the confidence interval values are wrong.
